reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s fat-tailed value-per-resource claim used to argue that, on linear (resource-separable) unbounded views, most resources must be used in very specific ways, making mostly-great futures a narrow target. That claim is a supporting pillar for one strand of the overall “no easy eutopia” case, but the position also has substantial independent support (e.g., multiplicative/fragility arguments; scale requirements without fat-tail exactingness; bounded-view fussiness via bads aggregation). So centrality is moderate (~0.3). On the attacked point, the critique has moderate strength: it correctly notes that several cited fat-tail examples are about competitive/instrumental domains and that the paper doesn’t fully derive an intrinsic-value fat-tail from first principles. It also raises a real worry about the paper’s quick inference from uncertainty to heavy tails. However, it doesn’t engage the paper’s additional intrinsic-value discussion (extreme experience examples/surveys) and doesn’t show the distribution is thin-tailed; it mainly undercuts confidence. Correctness is fairly high but not perfect: the “mathematical non-sequitur” charge is directionally right (mixtures don’t automatically have the desired tail properties), though mixtures often can be heavy-tailed depending on priors/weights, so the critique slightly overstates. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little dead weight.
title: Fat-tailed value distribution lacks theoretical grounding and misapplies empirical analogies
